title: About this product
body:
Who this product is for:

This learning product has been developed for the Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA) employees who have face-to-face interactions with internal or external clients of the CBSA.

Purpose of this product:

This product was created to provide the CBSA employees who have face-to-face interactions with internal or external clients, with awareness, knowledge, and strategies on managing diversity and race relations. This product is meant to either serve as a refresher to any classroom diversity training that the CBSA employees may have taken or as a learning product for the CBSA employees who may be new to the topic of diversity and race relations, and would benefit having this information, to conduct their job more effectively.

title: Learning goals
body:
The main goals of this Diversity and Race Relations web-based training are to:

  • Promote the understanding of key concepts related to diversity and race relations;
  • Provide strategies that the CBSA employees can apply, on the job, towards promoting a professional and equitable service to the CBSA's multicultural clientele, and employees; and
  • Act as a vehicle towards creating positive conversations in the workplace about diversity and race relations.

title: Learning objectives
body:
At the end of this learning product, you will be able to:

  • Define diversity related concepts and notions;
  • Understand the CBSA's business case for diversity and race relations;
  • Examine the impact of stereotypes, prejudices, discrimination, and biases when interacting with different cultures;
  • Identify strategies to provide equitable service to our diverse clients; and
  • Understand how dealing with diversity and race relations effectively will directly relate to our business.

title: Module introduction
body: Before we can look at what diversity and race relations are all about, we must first understand what they are not. Many people make claims about diversity and race relations that are not true. You will now review seven myths and the facts in the following exercises called Dispelling Some Myths.

title: Dispelling some myths
body:
Introduction

First, read the myth and then think about your views about the myth. Next, read the fact and then ask yourself, Is this consistent with what I currently believe?
instruction: Click on each button to reveal every myth

_items.title: Myth #1
_items.body:
Myth: Stereotyping is wrong and respectful people don't do it.

Fact: Intentionally or unintentionally, we all stereotype. The challenge is to be aware of our biases, our belief systems, as well as to recognize their impact on our dealings with others and the way we do our job.

_items.title: Myth #2
_items.body:
Myth: Diversity is just another version of Employment Equity.

Fact: Employment Equity is based on legislation and focuses on four designated groups (women, visible minorities, people with disabilities and aboriginal peoples).

Managing diversity is adopted by an organization on a strictly voluntary basis as a strategic business imperative. Managing diversity is a broader, more inclusive concept that goes beyond employment equity's four designated groups in addressing the need to create a fair work environment and to better service a diverse clientele.

_items.title: Myth #3
_items.body:
Myth: Diversity is mainly about race and gender.

Fact: Diversity is broader than race or gender. Diversity is any combination of individuals who are different in some ways and similar in others. This concept challenges us to abandon our accustomed ways of thinking about diversity.

_items.title: Myth #4
_items.body:
Myth: Being sensitive to diversity and race relations issues at the CBSA could jeopardize the security of Canadians.

Fact: The CBSA mandate is not negotiable. Canadians need to be confident that the CBSA is protecting their health, safety and economic prosperity.

On the other hand, managing diversity is not an option - there are legal, business and ethical imperatives for managing diversity. The challenge, and opportunity for front line workers is the balance between these two requirements.

_items.title: Myth #5
_items.body:
Myth: Diversity is a fad.

Fact: Diversity is a trend that is likely to continue for years to come. Look at our workforce and client base today and compare it to five and ten years ago.

Our future is a diverse one - providing an opportunity to create an environment where a diverse workforce can flourish and grow and allow you to serve a rapidly diversifying client base.

_items.title: Myth #6
_items.body:
Myth: Diversity is exclusive.

Fact: Diversity is inclusive. Diversity is not about getting "them" into your corporate culture (assimilation). Diversity is about creating a culture where each individual can thrive and contribute to the organization (integration/multiculturalism).

_items.title: Myth #7
_items.body:
Myth: Diversity is a problem that needs fixing.

Fact: Diversity is not a problem that needs to be fixed but an opportunity. It is a more efficient and integrated way of doing business that has become a fact of modern organizations, modern Canadian society and the CBSA.

title: Defining race relations
body:
In the context of training, the Canadian Race Relations Foundation (CRRF) uses the terms race relations and anti-racism training interchangeably.

If asked, most people could easily offer a simple definition of racism. In fact, the Oxford Dictionary offers the simplest definition of racism as "prejudice based on race", and this is how most people understand the concept. However, once we start to analyze this definition, it becomes apparent that racism requires a far more complex definition.

Did you know?
Driving the imported growth of the labour force is a low domestic birth rate and the advancing age of baby boomers. Baby boomers make up almost 50 percent of Canada's work force. Article in Ottawa Business Journal, "Immigrants account for 70% of labour force growth: Statscan", February 11, 2003.

title: Forms of race relations
body: Racism takes many forms, although it is usually understood in the individual sense. Essentially, there are three main forms: individual racism, systemic racism and cultural racism.
instruction: Select each form to read a description.

back.title: Individual Racism
back.body: Individual racism manifests itself in an individual's attitudes and behaviours. It is the easiest type to identify.

back.title: Systemic Racism
back.body: Systemic racism consists of the policies and practices of organizations, which directly or indirectly operate to sustain the advantages of peoples of certain "social races". This type of racism is more difficult to address because it is implicit in the policies of organizations and often unconscious.

back.title: Cultural Racism
back.body: Cultural racism is the basis of both other forms of racism, as it is the value system which is embedded in society which supports and allows discriminatory actions based on perceptions of racial difference, cultural superiority and inferiority.

title: Relevant legislation
body:
Diversity management is an essential competence in our increasingly global society. It is not only ethical and appropriate to treat the public equitably; it is required by law. There are consequences for individuals and organizations for not adhering to the provisions of relevant legislation.

Legislation related to diversity and race relations includes the:

  • Canadian Human Rights Act (CHRA)
  • Employment Equity Act (EEA)

"What Canada has to offer to the international community is a model that values cultural diversity but [also] recognizes that certain core values, such as equality, the commitment to a democratic way of life, and a sense of community, are becoming a fundamental characteristic of how we define ourselves as human beings."

Mary Gusella - Former Deputy Minister, Multiculturalism and Citizenship Canada

_items.title: Purpose
_items.body: Under the CHRA, it is against the law for any employer or provider of service to discriminate on the basis of 13 grounds.

_items.title: The Thirteen Grounds
_items.body: Under the CHRA, it is against the law to discriminate on the basis of 13 grounds: race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, age, sex, marital status, family status, sexual orientation, disability, and pardoned criminal conviction.

_items.title: Redress
_items.body: Redress against discriminatory actions is undertaken through the complaint process established under the Act, i.e., the Human Rights Commission.

_items.title: Focus
_items.body: The focus of the CHRA is internal to organizations, but also external relating to the provision of services.

_items.title: CHRA
_items.body: Canadian Human Rights Act

title: CHRA and diversity
body:
How CHRA relates to diversity?

The emphasis of the CHRA is not limited to understanding cultural groups. It goes one step further to ensure that people are not placed at a disadvantage simply because of their age, sex, race or any other ground covered by the Act.

"Every individual is equal before and under the law and has the right to equal protection and equal protection and equal benefit of the law without discrimination and, in particular, without discrimination based on race, national or ethnic origin, colour, religion, sex, age, or mental or physical ability."

Section 15 (1), Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, 1982

_items.title: Purpose
_items.body: The EEA is aimed at employment practices to make the Public Service workforce reflective of the people it serves, given the available qualified workforce. The purpose is to ensure the full integration and utilization of the different segments of the labour force.

_items.title: Designated Groups
_items.body:
The EEA attempts to correct the conditions of disadvantage or unequal treatment in employment experienced by four specific target groups:

  • Women
  • Disabled individuals
  • Visible minorities
  • Aboriginals

_items.title: Redress
_items.body: There are organizational consequences to not adhering to the provisions. Redress mechanisms subsequent to complaints and investigations can involve requirements to modify work practices, being subject to audits and, in some circumstances, financial consequences.

_items.title: Focus
_items.body: The EEA's focus is on equality in the federal Public Service so that no person is denied employment opportunities or benefits for reasons unrelated to ability.

title: Introduction
body: Differences between Employment Equity and Diversity
instruction: Click on each item below to view the definition.

_items.title: Equity
_items.body:
Legislated and externally driven

  • Employment Equity Act, 1995
  • Written plans and statistical goals for specific groups are utilized

Quantitative

  • Addresses workforce profiles
  • Achieving equality of opportunity in the work environment through the changing of organizational demographics
  • Ensures that workforce reflects community
  • Monitored by statistical reports and analysis

Exclusive

  • Narrow focus
  • Benefits four designated groups
  • Assumes that groups brought into the system will adapt to existing organizational norms

Reactive

  • Addresses past actions, e.g., workforce representation due to past hiring processes

_items.title: Diversity
_items.body:
Not legislated

  • Voluntary and internally driven
  • Moral and ethical and business imperatives drive this cultural change

Qualitative

  • Addresses workplace environment
  • Appreciation of differences, skill-building and creation of environment in which everyone feels valued and accepted
  • Ensures that differences are valued and managed appropriately
  • Monitored by organizational surveys focused on attitudes, and perceptions

Inclusive

  • All-encompassing focus
  • Benefits to all employees
  • Assumes that diverse groups will create new ways of working together effectively in a pluralistic environment

Proactive

  • Addresses current business and management issues, e.g., valuing diverse teams and customers

title: Duty to Accommodate
body:
Diversity is any combination of individuals who are different in some ways and similar in others. It also relates to the impact of differences on the individuals. To manage diversity effectively, we must acknowledge, recognize, and respond to these differences the best we can.

This leads to an important concept in managing diversity: the duty to accommodate.

Click on the arrow to learn more on the different parts of the diagram.

_items.title: Courts of Canada
_items.body:
The duty to accommodate is a legal obligation that was affirmed and clarified by the courts, including the Supreme Court of Canada.

However, the courts have recognized that the duty to accommodate is not open-ended. The Supreme Court of Canada clarified that employers and service providers must make sure they build accommodation into their policies and practices up to the point of undue hardship.

_items.title: Legal Obligation
_items.body:
The Canadian Human Rights Act (CHRA), the Employment Equity Act (EEA), along with established case law provide the legal impetus relating to the duty to accommodate.

An employer/service provider has the duty to take steps to eliminate/diminish disadvantage or unfair differential treatment of employees or clients that have or may have an adverse impact on individuals or groups protected under the CHRA or a designated group under the EEA.

_items.title: Undue Hardship
_items.body:
The Supreme Court of Canada clarified that employers and service providers must make sure they build accommodation into their policies and practices up to the point of undue hardship.

Accommodation may not be required if it can be shown that providing it could cause undue hardship to the organization.

The concept of undue hardship is a complicated one yet important. Although the courts have not provided a comprehensive definition of what is to be considered "undue hardship" in general: health, safety and cost are often the factors considered.

_items.title: Purpose
_items.body:
The duty to accommodate recognizes that true equality means respect for peoples' different realities and needs, as well as the accommodation of these realities and needs to the best of our or an organization's abilities.

The areas covered under duty to accommodate are factors resulting from such things as disability, sex, age, family status, ethnic or national origin, and religious beliefs.

_items.title: Focus
_items.body: The duty to accommodate refers to the obligation of an employer and a service provider to take steps to eliminate or diminish disadvantage or unfair differential treatment of employees and clients due to organizational rules, practices, or physical barriers that have or may have an adverse impact on said individuals or groups.

title: Policies and operational practices
body:
Treating people fairly is not only important but is embedded in the CBSA values, and points to how it treats its employees and its clients.

In addition, there are numerous other legislations and policies that can directly impact the standards and behaviours of the employees at the CBSA. These include the Official Languages Act and the Treasury Board Policy on the Prevention and Resolution of Harassment in the Workplace. The scope of these pieces of legislation and policies is far too big to include in this learning product.

"Understanding diversity in the workplace isn't about being 'Politically Correct' enough to know the right labels. It's about truly understanding where different kinds of people are coming from - and knowing how to avoid behaviour that leaves them feeling hurt, angry or left out."

Rene Blank, Sandra Sharp, Voices of Diversity, AMACOM, 1994

title: Policies and operational practices
body:
As you carry out your duties, keep in mind that there is a possibility that individuals may avoid answering questions, or hide something because of their diversity and/or cultural background.

For example, the individual is nervous, not consistent in his or her answers, documents do not seem in order, etc. It is important that you consider all the available information before making a decision about the situation. One piece of information is your awareness of diversity and cultural differences. Try not to assume. For example, ask the person to explain why and how their culture or customs impact their ability to comply or prevent them from discussing their situation with you. You could explain why the person needs to answer your questions in order to comply with the requirements of your position.

Diversity is one tool in your toolbox to help you do your job. However, diversity is not to be seen in isolation.

title: Introduction
body: A person's experiences and perspectives can often shape how he or she approaches and reacts to different situations. Many of these experiences and perspectives can be culturally or religiously based. Understanding, or at least appreciating the possible impact diverse backgrounds and experiences can have on your interactions with clients can be helpful in your job.
instruction: Some of the most common diversity related issues that can influence individuals when interacting with the CBSA employees are:

_items.title: Fear of law enforcement authorities or government officials
_items.body:
Given experiences and oppressive government practices in some countries, some individuals may be distrustful and even fearful of government employees. Some people can be quite fearful of individuals in uniforms.

As a public servant, you have powers and organizational resources, which may intimidate, confuse or overwhelm your client.

_items.title: Limited experience in dealing with women in positions of authority
_items.body:
The social and professional status of women is not the same throughout the world. This can be due to cultural, religious, or even economic reasons.

Consequently, some people of both genders may feel uncomfortable when dealing on a professional basis with women. This may lead to specific behaviours or requests. Some individuals' cultures do not prepare them for dealing with women in authority positions.

_items.title: Personal nature of private matters
_items.body: Given the political context in certain countries, there isn't a need to discuss private issues relating to family and finance with government officials. In other cases, there is sanctity associated with private affairs; therefore, discussing these matters with strangers is considered to be inappropriate.

_items.title: Style of verbal interaction
_items.body:
There are differences in the culture norms relating to how people interact. For example, looking at someone while they are talking can be viewed as not respectful while it is a sign of active listening for others. Hand gestures can also be a sign of disrespect and even threatening while it is common in some societies.

The formality associated to interaction can also be of importance. In societies where there is a strong and established class system, interaction tends to be formal and distant, while in other societies official interaction between strangers can be quite informal.

_items.title: Use of vocabulary in verbal interaction
_items.body:
Expressions and the meaning of words in English or French can vary from country to country or even within countries. It is important to remember that what may sound strange or potentially offensive may not be.

Furthermore, the speaking style and fluency of non-English or French speakers can often be impacted by their knowledge level of one of Canada's official language, or by the speaking style and grammar rules of their own language.

_items.title: Personal space
_items.body: North American's appreciation and views on the personal space is very different to the reality of individuals from other countries.

_items.title: Religious artifact
_items.body: Individuals can choose or, given faith, are required to bring certain religious articles with them. Several religions use different items for religious purposes. Handling of these artifacts requires specific conditions and traditions.

_items.title: Expectations
_items.body: Communication can contain an element of surprise; particularly when the individuals involved have lived different experiences. Individuals often bring different perceptions and ideas to an issue.

_items.title: Family hierarchy
_items.body: There are differences between matriarchal cultures versus the patriarchal ones. In addition, the position and the responsibilities of children in some societies can also differ. In some cultures, due to the economic or social circumstances, children are given responsibilities at an early age.

Our families, friends, peers, teachers, idols, books, and others have helped shape our perceptions about how we view things and how we respond to them.

In this section you will continue this reflective self-examination by looking at the assumptions that drive our behaviours.

Did you know?
If you shake hands with someone from another part of the world, remember that firmness of grip will vary from culture to culture. Most Germans have a very firm handshake, while people from Asia Pacific, South Asia and Latin America usually have a soft handshake. If you usually use a firm handshake, be on guard not to view a weak handshake as a defect in competency, i.e., that a person with a soft handshake is wishy-washy, passive or indecisive. Many men from Middle Eastern countries do not generally shake hands with women from their own culture and may feel very uncomfortable about doing so with women from North America.

title: The Platinum Rule
body:
Its easy to fall into the trap of generalizing and stereotyping. The challenge is to try to suspend your judgment about a person or a group of people, so that you dont react automatically to cues and make assumptions.

Many of us have learned the Golden Rule: Treat others as we would want to be treated.

In managing diversity, we need to take things one step further and apply the Platinum Rule: Treat others as they would want to be treated.

For reflection

What do we need to do in order to treat others as they would want to be treated?

We could get to know them more, ask them how they want to be treated. When you notice that you have perhaps upset them, ask them what you did to upset them how they would prefer to be treated.

_items.title: Discrimination
_items.body: Discrimination is an act of differential treatment toward a person or group, which usually creates a disadvantage for that person or group.

_items.title: Bias

_items.title: Why wouldn't you give a clock as a gift to your Chinese colleague?
_items.body: In Chinese culture clocks are associated with death and funerals. The sound of the word "clock" is similar to the word "death".

_items.title: What is Ramadan?
_items.body: Ramadan is the holy month of fasting for Muslims throughout the world. The start and end dates for Ramadan may vary because the beginning of Islamic lunar months depends on the actual sightings of the moon.

_items.title: Name the symbols worn by Sikhs
_items.body:
• Kanga: Comb. A symbol of hygiene and discipline as opposed to matted unkempt hair of ascetics.
  • Kirpan: Ceremonial Sword. A symbol of dignity and the Sikh struggle against injustice.
  • Kara: Steel Bracelet. A symbol to remind the wearer of restraint in their actions and a remembrance of God at all times.
  • Kachha: Drawers. A symbol signifying self-control and chastity.
  • Kesh: Long unshorn hair. A symbol of spirituality.

These are cross-gender symbols; both men and women wear them.

_items.title: Why is the OK sign not always okay?
_items.body: The OK sign has the same meaning in some countries as the middle finger in North America. Among people from Saudi Arabia it may also be interpreted as giving a curse. People from Latin America are likely to interpret it as: "Screw you!" For the French, it means that something is worthless - Zero. In Japan, it is a symbol for money (the fingers creating the round outline of a coin.

title: Elements of cross cultural communication
body: In our interactions with others, we need to be aware of language which appears to stereotype a group and behaviours that may violate the cultural rules of others. Consider each item below

_items.title: Words, images, and situations
_items.body:
• Words, images, and situations suggesting members of a racial group are the same

e.g., "Why can't Joe ever be on time?" "He's Haitian Canadian, isn't he?"

_items.title: Qualifiers
_items.body:
• Qualifiers reinforcing stereotypes

Example: "Sandra is not trustworthy. She never looks at you when you are speaking with her. Most people from her culture can't be trusted."

The lack of eye contact does not necessarily mean the person can't be trusted.

_items.title: Racial identification
_items.body:
• Avoid racial identification except when essential

Example: "Mrs. Woo, an attentive client," is preferable to, "Mrs. Woo, an attentive Asian Canadian client."

_items.title: Colour symbolism and usage
_items.body:
• Possible negative implications of colour symbolism and usage that could offend or reinforce bias

Example: Terms such as "black magic" can be offensive.

_items.title: Language connotations
_items.body:
• Language that has questionable connotations

Example: Phrases such as "culturally deprived" and "you people" have racist overtones.

_items.title: Attentiveness
_items.body:
• Rules for attentiveness

Example: Maintaining eye contact while listening during a conversation may violate a conversational rule in some cultures. In some societies, it is impolite to look at someboy directly.

_items.title: Distance between speakers
_items.body:
• Rules about distance between speakers

Example: In some cultures, speakers stand close enough to touch often. In other cultures, distance is maintained to denote respect.

_items.title: Humour and taboo
_items.body:
• Cultures and what they consider humourous or taboo

Example: Ethnic humour is often perceived by many groups as evidence of prejudice. Discussion of group cultural rules and behaviours with outsiders is considered taboo within many cultures.

_items.title: Taking turns to speak
_items.body:
• Rules for taking turns to speak

In some cultures, individuals frequently perceive "breaking in" to reinforce or disagree with another's point to be perfectly permissible, indeed desirable.

title: Ways to value diversity
body: To value diversity and to strive towards understanding diversity, you can:

_items.title: Be aware of groups and cultures
_items.body: Broaden your general knowledge of groups and cultures by asking questions and listening carefully.

_items.title: Be aware of your attitudes
_items.body: These are clearly transmitted both verbally and non-verbally. Your attitudes toward differences come from your life experiences, your values, and beliefs. Think about how your cultural norms and values may affect how you judge others.

_items.title: Be aware of your biases and prejudices
_items.body: Be aware of how they might affect your decisions about others and the way you interact with them.

_items.title: Be respectful
_items.body: Treat all people fairly, honestly, and with positive regard. Ask questions, listen carefully, check understanding.

_items.title: Be willing to look at your behaviour
_items.body: Be willing to change your own behaviour to avoid bias and prejudice to ensure you are being respectful and sensitive to all people. Try to give people a fair chance and the benefit of the doubt.

_items.title: Be willing to address inappropriate behaviour
_items.body: Be willing to address inappropriate behaviour by others such as derogatory comments or actions. Try to work on ways to become more verbal when you are aware of biases and prejudices.

title: Module conclusion
body:
In this module, you have had an opportunity to learn more about different cultures and to identify strategies to value diversity and communicate across cultures. In the module exercises, you have seen how the impact of your behaviour can have a positive impact on client service and CBSA operations.

While the CBSA doesn't expect or require you to change your behaviour outside of work, it is expected that your work behaviour must adhere to certain standards and expectations set by the organization. These expectations are more than just CBSA policies or wishes; they are based on our vision to be recognized and respected by clients for our integrity, fairness, and innovation in administering high-quality, affordable programs.

title: Instructions
body:
You started this product with three main goals:

  • promote the understanding of key concepts related to diversity and race relations;
  • provide strategies that the CBSA employees can apply, on the job, towards promoting a professional and equitable service to the CBSA's multicultural clientele, and employees; and
  • act as a vehicle towards creating positive conversations in the workplace about diversity and race relations.

title: Course Conclusion
body:
You started this product with the following learning objectives:

  • define diversity related concepts and notions;
  • understand the CBSA's business case for diversity and race relations;
  • examine the impact of stereotypes, prejudices, discrimination, and biases when interacting with different cultures;
  • identify strategies to provide equitable service to our diverse clients; and
  • understand how dealing with diversity and race relations effectively will directly relate to our business.

The CBSA is committed to equipping its employees with the necessary tools to work with an increasingly diverse public. One tool is this learning product. We encourage you to continue learning about diversity.

Remember, diversity is a journey, not a destination. We encourage you to take the time to reflect on your stereotypes, biases and assumptions when interacting with different cultures, and to develop your cultural curiosity as you journey forward.
